job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: Georgia Tech is really all what you make of it.  You can have the best time if you're in a good program with a good advisor; on the other hand, you can have a terrible time if you have a terrible advisor.  All in all, though, all of the engineering programs are top-notch and you will (if you make it through, that is) end up with a quality, respected, and solid education in engineering fundamentals.  If you want a PhD, Georgia Tech is a good place to do and living costs in Atlanta are fairly cheap.  Try and figure out what you like about it.
cons: The place is very high-stress but is manageable with good time-management.  Some of the departments (PARKING especially) are notorious for making students' lives hell, but if you know how to work the system you'll figure out what to do and what to avoid in order to avoid headaches.  It is absolutely necessary to have good time management skills; otherwise you can end up getting very far behind very quickly.  There is kind of a sense of depression and stress amongst the students here but there are still plenty of ways to keep yourself happy.  Try and avoid the parking department.

pros:
This review is for a STAFF position in one of the many administrative offices on campus. Yes, there are more than just students and faculty on campus; a university is a business and it takes people to run a business.

-Wonderful colleagues to work with!
-Beautiful college campus
-No overtime hours required (depending on the department and any ongoing projects)
-Excellent benefits and vacation time, especially once you reach past 5 years
cons:
-No room for career growth
-You're basically stuck in your job until you find a job in another campus department or off-campus
-Not easy to get a job transfer to another campus department
-Poor communication across campus departments
- I worked here more than 5 years and my job title, job description, and pay never changed; the person who replaced me is entry-level and right out of college. Jobs tend to stay that way at GT which is why you have to leave GT if you're ever going to grow or move up in your career, or own a home of your own.
-Pay is LOUSY. If you work in corporate doing the same job, you'll make double what GT pays (web development, communications, marketing, analytics, event planning, etc.).  
-If you have a trust fund, a wealthy spouse, or are close to retirement, or are a top level director in a campus unit, then GT is the place for you. Everyone else, look elsewhere!

pros: As a graduate student you have the opportunity to obtain a world class engineering degree that will leave you with a variety of different career opportunities.  The PhD program provides a challenging platform to develop your analytical and communication skills.  Unlike the PhD stereotype, my experience has helped greatly develop both my written and vocal communication skills.  The some programs are interdisciplinary and allow students to learn and syntesize concepts from a varitey of traditional disciplines.   Georgia Tech also offers a multitude of resources, including business and language classes, which most graduate students can utilize to obtain a well rounded education.
cons: Like most PhD programs, a timely and successful completion of the degree requires a substantial amount of work after regular hours and during weekends with little monetary compensation.  Perspective students need to be aware of the time and financial commitment required.

review_title: PhD student and Research Assistant in Georgia Tech: Pleas read this carefully before coming to Georgia Tech!
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: I have already spent three years of my life here in Georgia Tech, and when I compare my experiences to other students in other top ranked universities, I can't think of pros for Georgia tech, except that you would eventually graduate from an apparently prestigious university with a fake top rank which might help having more chance to hunt a better job.
cons: When it comes to the Cons of Georgia tech, It is a point of confusion as you don't know what to start with. As a student, you are the last thing in the world to be cared about in Georgia Tech. Salaries are way low in comparison to other universities and every month you have to pay around $500 as obligatory fees, which means literally 1/3 of the salary you get as an research assistant. There is nothing called student rights in this university. The system genuinely tries its best to rip students off. Professor can screw you in any ways they want, of course having the support of the university. Nothing is organized. The climate of the university is so depressing which would make you very uncomfortable.

pros: Gorgeous campus, incredibly accomplished faculty
cons: Incongruity, inefficiencies, below market pay

review_title: Lack of support from Supervisory, Management and does not exist from upper management
pros: Students, good education. Staff are nice and really work hard for the students. Students are awesome, focused - many will do great things.
cons:
No raises!! Supervisors and directors only interested in their own salaries, no support for increases in salary or job responsibilities except for those reporting to VP and of course upper management.  GT constantly Adding positions and bringing in outsiders. GT has added more administrators with six figure income than any institution-does not reward those on the front lines. 
No interest in helping staff move forward-most seem to want to discourage you from anything. Moral very low-focus on only those in academic area-Non academic area very low pay except for directors and VP or those who do the work for the VP.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: As a graduate research assistant, the staff at Tech is very good about giving you the technology and equipment you need to get the job done.  There are numerous computer software packages available to you for both work and home use, as well as providing an excellent grad student salary relative to the cost of living in Atlanta.  Also, fees and insurance can be deducted from future paychecks over the term, rather than paying up front.
cons: The main downside that I found was having to pay 100% of the cost of health insurance, and this insurance not including dental coverage.  Previous grad student employers of mine had included the cost of health insurance as part of the package.  In addition, the fees left for us to pay are rather high compared with other schools.  Full tuition is remitted, however fees and insurance typically leave the student employee with a bill of $1000 - $1200 per semester.

review_title: I like my work, my classes not so much.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: I'm very lucky to have a great job in my research area that supports me in my personal research as well as in advancing their aims; not all grad assistants are so lucky.  I love my work and I'm quite happy with most of it.  My job is somewhat flexible but I do have to put in desk time; I get the sense that I am in the minority of grad students on this.
cons: As a student who also works you will work VERY hard. There are almost no "easy" assistantships here as some schools have.  Also you work 13 hours a week plus take 3 very hard classes.  In many ways it's easier to take 4 classes if you can afford it.  We are also underpaid compared to many assistantships.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: Excellent institution for a STEM BS/MS/PhD degree - especially for those who are aiming to go into industry. Consistently ranked in the top both nationally and internationally. Excellent resources for research with a very diverse group of researchers. Huge career fair, and generally a lot of companies coming through campus to recruit. For in-state students the ROI is pretty astronomical (i.e. I made it through a BS and PhD with ~$20k student loans, and general PhDs leaving my department expect ~$90-100k salary).
cons: The fees for graduate students are a constant source of frustration. Most grads can expect stipends in the mid $20k range, and then expect to pay $1200 for fall/spring fees and $1000 for summer fees. Tack onto that $750 parking permits, and it gets to be a bit much for those of us commuting everyday. Also, for commuters specifically, traffic in Atlanta is pretty awful sometimes.

review_title: 4-7 years of torture for a shiny new PhD
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: It has a good reputation as a research university. A degree from here will (allegedly) get you a long way. The school is well funded, and the professors are well known. Classes are usually very worthwhile and you should be able to learn something new. Professors are given free reign on how they treat their grad students, so it could be a great experience, or the worst of your life. Be careful, and make sure you pick a good advisor or switch within the first year (first semester would be better).
cons: Very little to do outside of lab. Little sense of community amongst graduate student population (result of no central place to gather). Long and hard work hours, little immediate reward seen. Some professors are no shows, others are constantly on your back, criticizing/attacking your work with pesky phone calls at 3am. Its seriously been known to happen here.

job_title: IT Support Analyst in Atlanta, GA
pros: The opportunity to work on one of the nation's most thriving campuses in an urban environment cannot be understated. You have a plethora of resources at your disposal and a bunch of different programs available to you if you want to further your career by going back to school or sign up for training in different areas.
cons: The opportunity to make an impact in my role is very limited. I feel like higher level management doesn't value my work ethic nor do I feel like my job is secure. I feel like they could outsource our entire office at any moment and leave me without a way to take care of my family. The department is steady putting out fires instead of preventing them.

review_title: Good school where the administration does not get in way of your work.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros:
I have worked at Georgia Tech as a Research Assistant for several years during my doctoral program.  The pay is competitive, compared to what doctoral students get at other universities in my discipline.  HR has improved dramatically since I joined.  The gym is fantastic.

The school has done a great of job of letting me, along with my adviser, determine my focus.  It seems that most students can arrange this:  everyone I know here is getting paid for the dissertation work.
cons:
Living close to campus can be a pain.  Most of the areas are either fabulously expensive or cheap but crime-ridden.  I would recommend using the Marta train, which stops close to campus.

They require health insurance for students, and force some crappy policy on you if you don't prove that you are already covered.

review_title: Amazing academics and research. Horrible, bloated administration.
pros: Obviously it's a top tier school with a great and well-deserved reputation for being on the cutting edge. The academics are hard by design, and that's why the people take a Georgia Tech degree seriously.
cons: The paperwork side of things is unbelievably painful here. I'll have degrees from a couple other universities and none of them made things this difficult. I've had paperwork lost and been told that I had filled out the wrong form when someone in the office had given it to me the day before. I've heard of people accidentally getting sent degrees, despite not having actually graduated. And it's not a few isolated incidents. It's a clear pattern and everyone complains about it. Some departments are probably better than others, but it seems to be an institute-wide problem.

job_title: Administrative Assistant III in Atlanta, GA
pros: Work schedule can be mildly flexible and it has great benefits.  The atmosphere is relaxed to where you can feel comfortable in your work space.  You just really have to investigate the department you work in, it makes all the difference.
cons: The is a hierarchy of faculty to staff.  I my department (ME) the faculty are able to treat the staff with a somewhat demeaning manner with no real consequences.  This boost morale into a downward negative spiral.  The schedule is somewhat flexible, but working from home consistently (at least once a week) is far far from ever happening and pay does not meet market rates.  The work is overloading and it takes and act of Gawd to justify the need to hire anyone.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros:
-Great University.
-Professors and Administration that look out for each individual, and understand the stresses that everyone is under.
-Highly intense, so you will grow and learn quickly.
-Plenty of support structures for mental health, physical health, etc.
-Lots of perks (Awesome high-end equipment that is free for business or personal use).
cons:
-Highly intense and therefore stressful.
-Highly underpaid compared to national standard.
-Onboarding is non-existent: train yourself on everything, set-up your own email, etc....
-Administrative procedures are unnecessarily bureaucratic.
-IT security is a joke.

review_title: Georgia Tech is a very open and free university in which to conduct research.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: The research opportunities are fantastic at Georgia Tech. The strong interaction with industry and focus on near term applications greatly helps in securing a position after graduation. A broad spectrum of students and professors enables highly creative collaboration. No professor is unapproachable, and any will gladly setup a meeting at your request, with many holding an open door policy. You will never be marginalized, as the faculty realize that much (if not all) of the research work is done by the students. Overall, the atmosphere is one of openness and freedom that allows most students to thrive and produce their best work.
cons: The research assistanceship is not the highest offered nation wide, but is certainly generous enough to provide for the cost of living in Atlanta.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: Georgia Tech provides tons of opportunities of high quality education. One can easily find an expert in any field and easy to collaborate. It provides excellent services to future career and other aspects. It has great reputation and great projects with related organizations and institutions. Innovation is encouraged. For sure, one can be involved in cutting-edge knowledge training. Public transportation in this area is convenient. I love it!
cons: As a part-time worker, the salary is low. As a student, one needs to pay a tuition each semester which is equivalent to one month payment after tax. Residential rent on campus is very high, parking fee is also high because it locates in midtown. Traffic in midtown is very bad.

review_title: Georgia Tech provides an excellent work environment.
job_title: Senior Systems Support Engineer Manager in Atlanta, GA
pros: Georgia Tech provides and excellent benefits package, including an attractive (and solvent) pension program through the Teacher's Retirement System of GA.  The work environment is very flexible and a strong sense of community is prevalent.
cons: In the current environment, the uncertainty surrounding state funding levels and the lack of funds to give raises for a number of years has created some concerns among employee groups.  Additionally, the lack of income growth has contributed to the loss of intellectual capital to outside companies.

pros:
* I am getting a free Master's degree
* I learned an enormous amount about my field, myself, and the facts of life
* I have a few good colleagues/ friends to add to my rolodex
cons:
* Professors often do not know how to work together, and this is crucial for interdisciplinary work
* This is not always an environment that brings out the best in people

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: Working at Georgia Tech as a teaching assistant is a comfortable job which covers tuition (not all fees), which generally requires less than the contract's 13 hours per week. Professors in the Industrial and Systems Engineering department are generally able to accommodate research and study needs. The students you get to teach are absolutely brilliant.
cons: Class sizes are very large, and so the work load can spike during periods where homework and exams line up. The workload model seems to be shifting more responsibility with no shift in pay, so the deal is becoming worse for time. I am under the impression that Georgia Tech's Industrial and Systems Engineering department pays sub par with our high-end engineering schools.

review_title: Graduate work worth the effort in the end when you graduate.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: The secretaries, department heads and students are all extremely helpful. The research you work on is extremely interesting. The name on your resume causes companies to be interested in you if you have a well written resume.
cons: The pay is too low for the city of Atlanta. I realize we are grad students but 22K/year is in the poor level.  Additionally a lot of that pay goes to extra fees. You work extremely long hours (14+hours/day, did 18 at one point) as a graduate research assistant. There is no planned vacation days although technically you are allowed two weeks off which I have never seen occur. Finding / communicating with bosses can be difficult which sometimes leads to massive project slowdown.

pros: A very creative and intellectually stimulating place to work.  The faculty and students are exceptional.  There are many lectures, classes, business plan competitions, etc. that challenging your thinking.  I find most faculty, administrators and students open to new ideas and initiatives.
cons: Salaries have been frozen by the State of Georgia for the last 5 years.  Also, Georgia Tech HR limits salary increases for internal promotions to higher level positions by putting a 10% or 15% cap  for the new position regardless of the increased responsibilities and market value of the position.

pros: It has great facilities to do research.   Students are also very good in general, especially the graduate students.  The student body and also the staff is quite diverse.  And off course the weather is great.  Snow is rare, so you do not have to clean your car every winter.    The institute supports greatly student and staff travel.  The reimbursement is at par with the professor level even for graduate student.  That is quite generous.   No need of receipts for meals etc.
cons: Some of the support stuff are incompetent.  The institute is not very student fiendly.   It is more friendly to the institute employee.

pros: Georgia Tech has great facilities, a nice campus, and many intelligent, passionate, hardworking people.
cons: This advice is specific to a Chemistry graduate student, but may apply to other fields. Working in academia is a worse environment than industry. The pay is terrible and the work is hard. Worst of all it is very difficult to find a job when you are finished since you are overqualified for most entry level jobs and have little to no real world work experience. I think I would have been better off not going to grad school and just getting an entry level job in industry, then working up or changing fields.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros:
* Flexible hours and location; I get to choose where and when I work. (Ended up getting an office to do most of it, but before that, mostly worked at home)

* Gain experience presenting results to others, and preparing to properly communicate often technical details without the jargon
cons: * Unless you're working as part of a larger group, the research can be kind of isolating. If you're joining a project, prior work might not be documented well.

review_title: Great Opportunity for Part-Time student employment
pros:
There is a good at-job flexibility of the job functions performed throughout the shift
It doesn't take a very high level of thought to perform job function
There is a good social environment on the shift
cons:
It is based on a shift of several hours from opening to close. This means that there are a lot of shifts. Many of the shifts are at bad times. Sometimes getting shifts is very hard to coordinate with the rest of my life.
The pay is sometimes hard to justify the poor hours.

job_title: IT Support Professional Senior in Atlanta, GA
pros: Great benefits and environment. Academia. Great to be able to work with and support students and faculty that are creating cutting edge technologies and research.
cons: All of the schools or department vary widely when it comes to job duties and performance metrics and even pay. Many departments are top-heavy with too many managers. (I believe the reason for this was the very small or complete lack thereof of raises for many years around this past recession, so managers would create new positions for those they wanted to ensure got paid more, which lead to having some job titles and employees that didn't belong together.)

job_title: Senior Project Manager in Atlanta, GA
pros: One of the finest institutions. Great benefits. Some really brilliant young minds.
cons: Low salaries.  Projects are not staffed with the right resources to be successful. Processes are disjointed and do not make sense. There's not a healthy appreciation for talent because most people have been with the organization for a very long time and have no other frame of reference but the Tech way.

review_title: Nuclear department is great, bureaucracy can be a pain
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: Great culture in the NRE department-professors are great, very easy to talk to, and there's a lot of variety in research. Students are also very laid back-brilliant, but unpretentious and very willing to help each other out.
cons:
Bureaucracy is a mess; the nuclear department is part of the mechanical school, so student services is spread across maybe 3 buildings and 4 offices, with little indication of where to go if you need something. 

The financial aid and bursar's offices don't talk as much/as often as they should, so financial aid often doesn't appear on your statement until the last minute.

review_title: Still an excellent place to work
pros: State benefits are excellent. Multiple health insurance options, 401k matching (vested immediately) or option for TRS if you know you will be around for the long haul. Solid work life balance. Flexible schedule including telework options available depending on your position and supervisor.
cons: Once you are in it's hard to move up. Excellent performers are not necessarily rewarded through career advancement. Lots of office politics and backroom dealing if you actually want a promotion, which I suppose is typical. Supervisors and even Directors have little to no say in promotions. Ethics violations are embarrassing to the university, but the President has done his best to fix the structural issues that led to these incidents.

review_title: A solid employer where your success is primarily linked to your own self discipline.
pros: Very supportive community.  Generally a good environment to work where a strong work ethic is valued.  You don't need to "be seen" putting in long hours in the office per se.  Instead it is more important that you produce high quality work in a timely fashion.  This allows for a certain degree of flexibility that allows one to benefit from their own self discipline.
cons: Must stay self motivated as there isn't someone there to pay you on your back after every big achievement.  Also, money comes and goes with the state budget.  Some years can be tight and some plentiful.

review_title: If you want a safe non-challenging job then this is your place
pros: If you want an easy job, have kids and want a pretty easy gig then this is your place.  If you're far along in your career then I wouldn't recommend coming here unless it's a pit stop to have kids and then move on.  There are very smart people at the top but nobody really shares that knowlege.  The peer staffers are siloed and don't really communicate across other depts.  I'd say if you're just starting out it's probably a good first stop but I would say that it would be a place where a career goes to die. No mas.
cons: Pay stinks.  Mostly staffers are lcd. Some very smart people coupled with the lcd.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: People are working on cool stuff and everyone around you is super smart, so it's a great place for learning and discovering. It's also a pretty sweet campus too- tons of trees, not bad for biking, great (supposedly the best in the country) rec center, lots of food options.
cons: As a graduate student, you'll likely be somewhat of a slave, and the school isn't well known for professors who listen to or care about their students. Can't say I had a ton of fun doing my master's here or working with my advisor. On a logistical note, parking is terrible and expensive.

review_title: Graduate Reseach Student: Fairly good, relativly speaking
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: Georgia Tech has some very well rated graduate programs with a number of top quality research groups and solid funding. Graduate programs are never wonderful (which is good so that people leave) but Tech's is a fairly good option overall.
cons: By constantly pushing to be top tier and compete in rank with private research institutions, Tech has increased pressure on itself which creates loads of bureaucratic frustrations.

review_title: Great Grad School Environment but absolutely not affordable anymore
job_title: Graduate Student Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: Great School, Great Programs, Great Facilities, Amazing  City
cons: Grad students are horribly underpaid. After a $2-3K in student fees over the year and a $1k parking pass you're left just above the poverty line. The campus is in the middle of Midtown, which has become one of the most expensive places to live. Average rents around the campus have skyrocketed and the average student can't afford them. The faculty refused to give pay raises to the students over the basically the last decade which has resulted in it being a miserable and depressing experience for most students

review_title: A lot of room for exploration, personal growth, and meeting professionals.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: A lot of room for exploration, personal growth, and meeting professionals.There are lots of experts in their fields and lots of room for collaboration for projects. The school is well funded for research and has lots of resources for continuing your project.  My program also offered free health insurance for graduate research assistants.
cons: The area has a bit high rate of crime since it is close to the downtown Atlanta. The administrative process can take a bit time to get processed.

pros: the environment in general is friendly, and there are a lot of cross-disciplinary collaboration, the campus is big, the campus recreation center is really good, there are some nice new buildings, and Tech Square is really convenient - with shuttle to MARTA station that goes directly to airport
cons: different department have different culture and politics, like every place else. atlanta traffic is insane, fortunately midtown area where the campus is located is walkable with lots of restaurants. Tech Square does not have really cheap street food

review_title: Lifeguard CRC: Still have fond memories of my time there
pros: Decent pay for part-time student, learn valuable skills, regularly train in life saving and swimming, meet lots of other fun people, see/work big events (duel in the pool/winter nationals), flexible scheduling. Loved my time there obviously.
cons: Early start for morning shift can be difficult. It can be a little slow when theres one person swimming laps and you're on stand but that's only 20 min at a time. there was no employee parking at CRC so I had to park in my designated area on campus which wasn't so bad for me but I can see that being an issue depending on your parking pass. I'm honestly thinking hard trying to come up with something more significant. No real cons.

pros: One of the largest engineering schools in the US. I am a PhD student in the Department of Industrial Engineering, the largest of such type in the US. This leads to a great choice of faculty to work with, many side projects to get involved in, and a dazzling selection of graduate coursework. There are research seminars with external speakers several times a week, which again allows for much breadth. Atlanta is also a great place for industry collaborations, with much logistics and supply-chain related industry as well as healthcare.
cons: The department is large and fractionalized, so you have to be outgoing to get to know professors and other students.ll as healthcare.

review_title: Just another Federal Funded waste and spend organization - just a lot smarter making it look good to taxpayers
pros: At GTRI you learn a great deal about how the federal funding dictates the activities of the majority of efforts undertaken there.  The upside is one sees how the federal government and civilian live are two different realms.
cons: The culture is one of intellectual elitism and what and how many degrees you have will place you in the pecking order.  Real world experience carries no water there - if you do not have an advanced degree you are but someone to tolerant.

review_title: This organization is intent in ensuring the education of its athletes.
job_title: Study Hall Monitor in Atlanta, GA
pros: Working with young college students is always a great feeling; as most are anxious to learn what you have to teach.  Teaching different course work; not in a classroom environment.
cons:
late hours ; by the time you commute its 10:30pm; only 1.5 hr per day.
the rate of pay is mediocre (not bad) but the amount of hours is horrible.  Can't live off this income or anywhere near it.  Hope you like working 3 jobs, cause this one job isn't significant enough to pay bills.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Atlanta, GA
pros: The school is well ranked and has a lot of good research opportunities. The professors and staff are, for the most part, very good.
cons: Graduate students must pay fees every semester (+$1,000 per semester) and the GRA and TA stipends are not that competitive compared to other universities. There is not a lot of affordable housing in the area for graduate students, and the campus housing is not very good for the price. There is not much of a feeling of community between graduate students that is present at many other universities.

review_title: Nice place to work for good benefits
job_title: Systems Support Engineer II in Atlanta, GA
pros: The insurance benefits are very good, as well as the ability to pay into the Teacher's Retirement System even as staff.  Casual atmosphere.  If you like science journals, you have access to all paid subscriptions from the library.  Large gym and Olympic pool on campus, but  requires extra fee
cons: Parking is terribly expensive ($600/year) and I have frequently had to deal with tons of red tape.  We have recently had to have furlough days, and I have had no raises for a few years, but they have not laid off a single person that I know of.

review_title: Good in engineering, poor in sciences and math
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: It is highly reputable technical institute for engineering but not for sciences. It is in a midst of a city like Atlanta so there is a lot of industry interaction. Many top recruiting firms come to recruit here.
cons: The Electrical Dept is too big and it is no longer a very selective institute in terms of admissions. So the student quality has reduced drastically over the years. The library is not good at all and you are not compensated well as there is no uniformity in the salary structure.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: Georgia Tech is an awesome community and campus. I have greatly enjoyed being a PhD student at this cutting-edge institution. Atlanta is fun and always has something new going on, and GT is in the center of it all. The people at GT, for the most part, are very friendly and intelligent. Some of the world's most intellectual individuals work at this school.
cons: The faculty advisors aren't always trained in how to be a great manager. Grad students are expected to work long hours in order to finish tasks on a tight schedule.

pros:
Well defined mission and good leadership. I'm a temp employee, and my hours are flexible. I've overheard some complaints from shift workers who are non-officers concerning the shift hours, but I've also heard positives. It seems to be more of a personal preference issue. 

I've been given a lot of freedom to perform my assigned duties in a manner I see fit. No micromanagement and no looking over my shoulder. The only thing that matters is the end product and I prefer this method of management.
cons: Work environment (as far as the facility itself) is not ideal. The building is old and in need of repair. Limited opportunities for temp workers as we've been hired for specific tasks.

pros: Job security, great benefits, education is encouraged, and generally good people to work with. Job growth is supported and pushed for. Diverse work place both ethnicity and gender.
cons: Low salary, no raises in 4 years because it is a government job. As staff faculty can treat you badly and get away with it in some schools/colleges. Even as IT you are/can be viewed as subordinate. Parking is expensive at $700. Bad employees are hard to get rid off.

pros: Relaxed atmosphere, just get your stuff done and you will have time to study at work.  The job paid pretty well, I was making 11.50 an hour as a senior and got a lot of free food to take home.  I was able to network with the administrators in the office and get career advice from them.
cons: At times repetitive and boring, but that is a consequence of having an easy job.  I had to work on Friday evenings until 8 and sometimes Saturday and Sundays.

review_title: Smart people who care about students
job_title: Employee Relations Consultant in Atlanta, GA
pros: Students are a priority at GT, as they should be. Smart people innovate and GT develops great minds who make big contributions to our world.  The campus is attractive and most employees have a real commitment to their jobs and to the University.
cons: For all the technology and resources thrown at students and teaching faculty, staff are sadly neglected and left to    struggle with outdated tools from the 1980s. At some point, staff need the President and senior managers to realize that investing in them will positively impact more than just the staff.  When staff have the tools they need, they can do more for faculty and students.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: Nice atmosphere, you get to work with very smart people, most professors are really good at teaching and research, which is a rare thing to find  in most universities.
cons: It may be hard to adapt if you lack some specific background and is assigned to a Teaching Assistant position within that area. Atlanta is expensive, so have that is mind. Lastly, I'd say: if you don't love doing research, don't start a PhD.

review_title: GTAH Review: Rewarding for GT Students and Sport Management/ Hospitality Students
job_title: Suite Attendant/Ticket Attendant in Atlanta, GA
pros:
Decent pay for part-time, not minimum wage
Everyone's pretty friendly as long as you do what you're supposed to
Sometimes you get access to free food (very valuable to college students)
Abundant networking opportunities because you're dealing with GT's elite alumna and business partners
Not a huge time commitment  at all (works great with college student schedule)
cons:
Dress code is kinda strict so in the winter prepared to be cold
Long hours on your feet (must wear comfortable shoes, I suggest sneakers)
Must commitment to work schedule, if something comes up you better have a good excuse
High turnout rate

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Atlanta, GA
pros: Great environment to work in. Excellent choices on affordable benefits for whole family and good vacation/PTO accumulation. Amazing retirement plan matching. All typical of staff on the University System of Georgia.
cons: As research staff, and as with all Universities, it really depends on who you work for. Group professors are notoriously impatient with progress so you will have to always excel beyond your abilities to progress. Pay is never great for early stage researchers and working hours far exceed industrial standards.

job_title: Ph D Graduate Student in Atlanta, GA
pros: I really like working at Tech. Overall, everyone is super friendly and professors are always willing to help you or provide you with advice, even if they are not in your committees or departments. I think professors/researchers at Tech are very passionate about the work, and it shows how much they enjoy it and they want to help you.
cons: Tech professors expect a lot from you. Research tends to be focused on basic science (how something works? how we make create something new that works this or this way), so it is definitely a lot tougher than other universities in which a Ph.D. simply entitles application of a product or probing different theories.

review_title: Anywhere in GT except College of Computing
job_title: Computer Services Specialist III  in Atlanta, GA
pros: It's a state job.  This means somewhat decent benefits and you get most major holidays off.
cons: This is specific to the College of Computing: the Dean and his cabinet have NO IDEA of how business is really executed at the college.  There is a lot of shifting money around and other suspicious activity financially.  Not to mention that the IT department at the College of Computing is the worst in the whole University.  They are known by the central OIT and other groups as the College of Compromises because they get compromised (hacked) so much.

pros: Great work/life balance, good benefits, lots of amazing things going on around campus. There's never a shortage of interesting projects. Overall, very collegial atmosphere. Beautiful campus in the heart of downtown Atlanta. High level of job security.
cons: Limited opportunities for professional growth. Old school management structure and processes. Most people tend to leave only when they retire. Projects and people move very, very slowly. Pay is low compared to private sector.

pros: Great staff and attitude in the work place. There is time to complete tasks like homework or other tasks. They are trying to create more tasks and projects for this job to make it more involved.
cons: Job is not very involved so there is a lot of downtime currently. It is a customer service type of job so there will be a negative phone call every now and then.

pros:
Great work/life balance.
Competitive or better pay than other public higher ed universities.
Great people.
Exciting and interesting work.
Great benefits including 14h of vacation and 8 hours of sick leave accrue per month, annual education support leave allowance, great healthcare, great retirement benefits and pension for faculty.
cons:
Some managers need better management training.
Can take along time to see progress in areas that need change.
Difficulty in getting consensus between offices.
When multiple offices are involved, no one wants to own the football and carry it into the end zone.

review_title: EHS is great! The people are nice and the work is reasonable. Very flexible with your class schedule.
job_title: EHS Student Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: The people are nice and the work is reasonable. Very flexible with classes schedule, and the work you do is easily comparable to working as a full time employee.
cons: The office has a low male to female ratio, meaning there are more females than males. This has lead to an increase in the amount of office drama, and gossip.

review_title: Engineering Graduate School- the worst qualities of industry and academia
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros:
-Overall, the student health insurance is good coverage

This applies to the Woodruff School of Mechanical Engineering:
-Tools and technology available for students to use for personal projects
cons:
-Bait and switch on stipends: health insurance is paid out of the stipends
-Students are not notified that a significant amount of fees are required for the privilege of attending as a student while working there (even if only thesis credit hours are being taken)
-No flexibility in opting out of any fees
-Grad school everywhere- long hours, low pay

review_title: Great school but a mess behind the scenes.
job_title: Principal Research Scientist in Atlanta, GA
pros: Flexibility, Nice campus, benefits and match
cons: Extremely bureaucratic processes and decision making; draconian compensation methods for all except some faculty and administration/finance staff; not agile; systems/processes are archaic and silo'd; knee-jerk reactions to media; ethics issues and employee morale at all-time low.  Ethics is a real issue and everyone is out to CYA.

review_title: Overall a great experience but some issues of mental health
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Atlanta, GA
pros:
- Great on and off-campus resources. Professors are happy to discuss research with students
- Overall a great environment of peers. GA Tech hires great people.
cons:
- It seems like Faculty are not incentivized to actually advise students (major push for grant money and publications)
- Graduate student mental health really suffers in some research groups. On campus help is provided but not actually effective because discussions do not include the Faculty who are part of the issues

review_title: Lots of Money, but Bad Dispension
pros: Lots of opportunity to work on cutting edge practices and software development, strong connections to companies that are large and matter, strong connections to individuals in the education and research world who know people all over.
cons: Payment schedules are unreliable for undergraduate assistants. If you have time to sort through the various levels of paperwork you can get paid on time, but it is far too easy to slip through the cracks and then require a month to get back on track. Not good when it's your primary source of income. Frequently asked to work a rough schedule or get things done on weekends.

review_title: Pays better than other USG institutions, but things move very slowly
pros: Best health insurance you'll ever have. Pay is better than at other USG schools. There's some flexibility in the work schedule (though not enough).
cons: Pay is still below market. And, everything moves at a snail's pace. Technology is worse than at an industry job. Be prepared to spend at least ten per cent of your time sorting through policies and red tape. Plus, many of the managers don't have actual management experience or training which leads to much frustration amongst staff. Not a lot of room for growth in many departments.

review_title: Extremely enriching, but disconcerting at times.
pros: Fair salary for the Atlanta area.  Enough to get by.  Research faculty are top notch and the facilities are competitive with anywhere other university in the country.
cons: Administration are not fully appreciative of their employees.  Very rigid on protocol, raise fees for graduate students every few semesters.  While my immediate boss, who is my contact for all of my research, was amazing, the administration of the institute was quite rude and unpleasant.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: Regardless of your lab or department, the Georgia Tech atmosphere is electric. GT continues to promote startups and new labs in Tech Square and getting companies to hire our students. We always rank highly in the engineering departments, and there is always something going on in terms of research development. Also, Atlanta is a great town that is currently growing rapidly.
cons: Work can be intense at times or before deadlines. Some labs are much better than others - there is little to stop a PI from running you ragged.

review_title: Great overall experience for graduate school!
pros: Georgia Tech is located in a very great area of an up-and-coming city.  Lots of cool things are happening around here.  And on top of that, Georgia Tech has a great deal of resources to help you do whatever it is you want to do!
cons: The pay as a graduate student is generally is not very good.

review_title: Graduate research assisants need to think carefully about joining this competitive research institution.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: As a research assistant at Georgia Tech, you can earn a PhD and a somewhat livable income at the same time.
cons: The system of biological, biomedical science, and engineering education at the level PhD is deeply flawed in the US.  There is little oversight as graduate research assistants enter the fiefdom of an academic lab.  Waste, abuse of power, manipulation, and mismanagement of graduate research assistants by driven, high profile academics unfortunately seems to be the rule, not the exception.

review_title: Interesting and fun environment with pay on the lower end.
pros: There is a lot of flexibility in terms of work schedule, a wide variety of projects to work on, great benefits, and overall it's an exciting environment.
cons: Pay is very much on the low end of the scale, career growth opportunities must be created by the individual (in my experience management focuses heavily on career development of teaching faculty and less on research faculty). On the flip side opportunities for taking classes to get an additional degree abound if the employee is willing to take the initiative.

review_title: A world-class engineering and science education in a challenging environment.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: Some of the best researchers in practically any engineering field can be found at Tech. As a graduate research assistant, you will be driven to high achievements.
cons: Administration as an entity can be a bit distant, though there are many individuals eager to help. Some professors can be very difficult to work for.

job_title: Applications Developer in Villa Rica, GA
pros: Great benefits, work-life balance, pleasant work atmosphere (except for a couple of co-workers), and good operational support. If you are looking for good work life balance and can afford the low pay, this is the place for you.
cons: A lot of politics / red tape, which stalls innovation and performance. Something that should take a week to get done takes months. Pay is about 25 percent below industry standard. The benefits are above standard (Medical / Retirement - Pension).

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: Depends on your advisor(s), but mine were both really good. I was able to perform research for my PhD work and for some other projects related to my field.
cons: Sometimes finding an advisor with an interesting project and funding is difficult. I knew people that started at GT with the promise of an RA position, but the only available positions were outside of the specialty they were interested in, so they ended up leaving.

review_title: Wish PhD students have only do research to get paid.
job_title: Research & Teaching Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: lot of collaboration opportunities, it is pretty competitive in all fields of academic life which keeps you motivated, many facilities for doing research, environment is supportive in few ways,
cons: there is limited financial support available. No raise in most cases even after number of years of work in the same position with performance.

pros: Nice environment to work in. There are many areas in which to work including academic, such as faculty, program manager or student advisor or non-academic, such as administration or facilities and grounds. It is a large place and there is a need for just about any area. The culture is pretty open in general but it also depends on the particular area you are in. Very good benefits and retirement plans if you stay for 10 years or more.
cons: Lockstep salaries and small raises. Promotions are few and far between. Bureacratic constraints restrict job efficiency. Very hard to get rid of non performers.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: Some of the best reasons to work at Georgia Tech as a Research Assistant include the flexibility of the faculty in meeting deadlines and the near-infinite amount of resources (knowledge-base) available to get work done.
cons: The major negative in being a Graduate Research Assistant is that faculty members are often busy, and have very little time to tend to the needs of their students.

review_title: Great place to learn many skills, but difficult to get through the politics
job_title: Research Scientist I in Atlanta, GA
pros: It's a fairly large organization, so it's easy to find people with similar interests and knowledge base to discuss and resolve problems. It's a great place to learn new skills and diversify, however sometimes it does not match with the current industry trends.
cons: As a state institution everything has to go out to bid, so our own expertise is never utilized when making decisions or implementing solutions within the organization.

pros: Good name, located in mid town, global fame, attracts good students from the globe, winter is not biting cold, many options to rent lease or own houses or apartments
cons: location is bad for research as it is situated in mid town, lots of crime just outside the campus, not safe for after dark commute, very hot during summer

pros:
The time goes by fast, with the help of the other cooks to keep you pumped and moving.
It's fun and everyone has a great time working with each other.
cons:
It gets extremely hot in the kitchen, and here in the summer time its even more exhausting. 
The truck sometimes will not arrive when scheduled,  but something you can't control. So the day must go on.

pros: You get free housing and a meal plan, which are amazing benefits if you are out of state. It is a fun interactive job that is very rewarding, especially knowing you are helping fellow students.
cons: This job can sometimes involve a lot of paperwork depending on how many resident you have/if you have apartments in your area. It also is disappointing when residents aren't enthusiastic and don't come to events.

review_title: A sick tenure system that breeds incompetence and poor behaviour
pros:
- Amazing facilities
- Great research culture
- Fantastic campus
- Ideal location
cons:
If you end up with a monster of a boss, you will have no recourse or options. You just get bullied until you quit.

HR and finance are a nightmare, HR especially. No one picks up the phone and there is no accountability,

Accountability in general is a problem - tenured staff are not made accountable for their actions, inactions, and decisions. Some are great people who are very ethical, but there are plenty of lazy, entitled, shiftless, useless stuffed suits who do nothing but take up space.

You can spend your whole life at work and it's never enough.

review_title: Great place to work but don't plan on getting paid competitively
pros:
management is understanding to personal issues
flexible work hours
very knowledgeable co-workers
sense of pride
widely recognized university
diverse faculty/staff/students
open to telecommuting
cons:
underpaid - Due to the state budget reductions, there have been no raises between 2008-2011 (and 2012 doesn't look good)
have to change departments to get promoted
have to pay to park on campus
very limited training budget
some management is "old school" as far as "if you are working from home, you aren't working"

review_title: it is pretty nice, good environment, nice professors
pros: You can learn a lot from the professors and also concentrate on your own interesting problems. People are brilliant here and they can understand where your problems lie in quickly.
cons: You have to work hard at Georgia Tech. It is not the place where you can relax and have good achievement. You have to really devote into what you are doing now, otherwise, your professor can tell.

pros:
Friendly department - regularly sponsors social events for grad students and faculty
State-of-the art labs and facilities 
Flexible work schedule - there's a lot of work, but you generally get to chose when to do it
Proximity to Emory makes inter-university collaboration more feasible 
The health insurance is really good
cons: Graduate student compensation is low. Honestly, I really loved working here, but the the graduate student stipend is no more than enough to live off of in Atlanta.

review_title: Great city to live and got a great degree.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: Georgia Tech is a great engineering school with lots of opportunity to do research.  Some faculty are sincerely interested in helping students succeed but will not baby you.  Atlanta is a great city to live with good food, sports, museums, and shows.
cons: The pay is not great and prospective grad students should be careful who they choose to be their advisor.  Parking fees are expensive and food in the dining halls are bad.

review_title: If you can find good management, working here is okay. Better than unemployment.
pros: For a non-faculty employee, the best reason to work at Georgia Tech is to be in the Teachers' Retirement System, hands down. Other benefits are available, but expensive. The academic departments are very busy during school, but the presence of the students lends an energy that you can't get anywhere else.  Younger employees who want to advance have to take advantage of every possible new opportunity and earn advanced degrees. Remaining long in one department may eliminate any hope of moving up, and those who are politically savvy and have a good work ethic will be successful.  If you can get on at GTRI, it is generally the best place on campus, but you must expect to work.
cons: Beginning 2014, the university is entering its sixth consecutive year of no merit raises. The old mantra of "work smarter, not harder," is worn out because the volume of work increases annually, while the hiring moratorium in place for at least the past six years continues on.  Morale is low. Little is done to empower staff to find ways to improve their own work situations.  Whiners and manipulators have the most power.  Those who have time to build retirement elsewhere have already left and the ones in the market to take their places have limited skills, so the quality of the talent pool sinks lower with each passing year.  Those with many years' experience are looking to retire as soon as they can unless a miracle happens and they find a better opportunity.  It is a disappointment to those who remember Georgia Tech as a real community of support where creativity and quality work was rewarded financially.

job_title: Instructor of Economics in Atlanta, GA
pros: Given that it's Georgia Tech, the students are smart and I enjoy teaching them. There's little to no micro-management from the department chair or Ph.D. Program director (I am a Ph.D. student teaching independent, not as a Teaching Assistant).
cons: The Economcs program is small and hence most students in my class are from other majors. But that's not really an issue. Students from other majors also show interest in Econ if you can motivate them.

review_title: Great resources, peers, and work environment
pros: Helpful approachable faculty means you can get the expertise you need. Two cleanrooms and numerous other user facilities means you have all the equipment get your work done.
cons: Some lab groups can be like fiefdoms... generally best to contact a grad student in the group and have them ask their advisor on your behalf.

pros: GaTech is a good research university to work. They have very good facilities and dedicated staff work for it. Recommended for those who try to find a postdoc or Ph.D. candidate position.
cons: It is located in downtown Atlanta, so driving is very time consuming. Parking is also costly. So suggest to use alternative way to get to school. There is Marta train and techtroley. I combine these two to come to work. It is a bit time consuming, but that is reality. Anyway, Atlanta is a big city and cannot expect like a small town/city.

pros: Some professors are really good. Depends whom you work with. The quality also depends from the department to department - there are strong ISyE, BioEngineering and Computer Science departments. Other departments might not be funded as well.
cons: Low salary, Support staff is terrible - administration is focused on making life easy for themselves. Class registration system is a nightmare. Refunds for expenses take months. A lot of travel regulations, for example receipts for dinner/lunch need to be saved, while receipts for taxis are not needed.

pros: Able to participate in advanced scientific research.  Nice campus.  Strong reputation in undergraduate and graduate studies.  Full tuition for graduate research assistants.
cons: High student fees are levied every semester on GRAs, even when no classes are taken.  High athletic fee that goes to support the varsity sports teams, which may not be of interest to some students.  This fee was increased the year GT fired their football coach, who had 4 years and $4 million remaining on his contract.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: The best pro of being a Graduate Research Assistant is that it allows to focus on some topic you are interested in. Another really good point is the time flexibility.
cons: Usually it required more hours than how the contract specifies; but since is a research in a topic of interest, this is not such a negative aspect!

pros: The hours are flexible according to class schedule. You get paid for planning PLUS sessions and meeting with professors. The experience itself is fulfilling because you get to help your peers understand difficult subjects in that you excel.
cons: Sometimes the students will not cooperate or get involved with your lesson plans and it is important to learn to adapt with their learning styles.

review_title: Great transition from corporate career to campus
pros: Tech has an excellent reputation and is highly ranked among academic institutions.  Colleagues and students are intelligent and easy to work with. The President is an exceptional leader who is very approachable.  The campus is beautiful, has plenty of amenities, is constantly being improved and is an energetic environment to be in. Work/Life balance is excellent.
cons: Crime is an issue for urban campuses. The faculty and student body could be more ethnically diverse.  Compensation provided by state institutions is not aligned with performance.

review_title: Good place to work if you enjoy Atlanta and football
pros: It's about on par with other educational institutions. Culturally if you're interested in football there are a ton of events and a strong community spirit built around that.
cons: This is personal bias but I'm not a huge fan of Atlanta as a city and it's smack dab in the middle. Parking on campus sucks and there's a decent amount of crime since it is in Atlanta.

pros: Convenient transportation on campus, good dining service, multiple on campus apartment choices, knowledgeable professors, very easy access to other cities through Atlanta airport.
cons: Food is bit expansive on campus and mostly American food, not very diversified. Public transportation is not convenient outside campus (Atlanta), so a car is a must. Limited campus entertainment, workload is high for student, quite competitive environment.

review_title: A great school, but a difficult place to work.
pros: Georgia Tech has a well-deserved reputation for being a great school. Working around the best and brightest students is a treat. The energy and diversity on campus are wonderful.
cons: Surprisingly, GT has poor technology for staff members. Many silos on campus keep people apart, and prevent good communications. Professors have a well-defines career path, but no one else at GT does - the professional development classes are a mixed bag: some are good, but some are outdated and not a good use of time. The benefits package is complex and difficult to understand. It was difficult to get anyone in HR to answer questions - they usually refer questions to a website.

review_title: A prestigious university full of great opportunities for students.
pros:
- On-campus employment a breeze to apply for. 
- Work schedules can usually fit class schedules. 
- Great community of fellow students and friends. 
- Being a part of the #4 engineering university in the nation. 
- The Campus Recreation Center is the #1 rated rec-center of any university in the nation.  
- Georgia Tech is nationally renowned as being a green campus and has beautiful landscaping.
cons: - Academics are very rigorous and can be difficult if the proper amount of time is not dedicated to studies.

pros: Great culture, good benefits, & decent opportunities for advancement for those willing to work hard.  On the faculty side there is a lot of solid talent and the education/research reputation is world class.
cons: Lots of bureaucracies that hold GT back from being more innovative in its administrative practices, low performers can often hide in the midst of this bureaucracy making it difficult to make progress. For those who patience in dealing with this, its not a deal breaker for making a good career working at GT.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: I get to give back to the Georgia Tech community and help freshmen ease into their college career. I enjoy teaching students. It makes me a better communicator.
cons: It is hard to gauge where the students are sometimes in terms of understanding the material. I hold office hours twice a week but most of the students think that they are above getting the extra help.

review_title: Working As A Undergraduate Lab Instructor at the Invention Studio
job_title: Undergraduate Lab Instructor in Atlanta, GA
pros: 24/7 Access to the invention studio, which is equiped with cutting edge manufacturing equiptment. Also, give the ability to teach others how to use these machines, and give general advice on designing.
cons: If you live on the wrong side of campus, the 24/7 access is somewhat a moot point, as you are limited by your ability to make it to the studio.

pros:
Great location, beautiful campus, nice office and department building, Okay benefits. 
Great department late leader.
cons: Unfair with the tenure process, departmental and higher management give wrong advice and do you big injustice, despite their describing your performance as stellar.  No mentoring or opportunities for professional development. No support at all.

pros:
-highly diverse research and job opportunities for students
-very effective HR, paperwork is minimal and generally, interaction with HR is hassle-free
-many research groups take employees from backgrounds outside of the institution
cons: -sometimes, for prospective TAs or RAs, their responsibilities are not clearly defined, and the responsiveness of project leaders or professors can be inconsistent

pros:
Young environment
Fresh Ideas
Encouraging Environment to pursue ideas 
Patient & proffesional bosses at the beginning 
Good infrastructure to support research
Not departmentalized.  Different Departments work well together
High quality work
cons:
Limited oversight (but that helps creativity)
Demanding Job 60-80 hr weeks (depends on boss)
Your boss will work even harder than you so you don't have an excuse for working only 40 hr
Stressful, frustrating 
Bosses have absurdly high standards
High turn-around people can can get burnt out easily

pros: Very collaborative - it's the norm here to work across departments, colleges and engage with the greater business community.
cons: A house divided - The university does not own your patents but a separate non-profit, does and they don't have the resources to file patents or hire decent attorneys. Also, you don't get to directly work with the patent attorney's - one of few under-resourced areas at Georgia Tech.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: International students at Georgia Tech get full tuition waiver when they work with a professor as a 100% research assistant. This goes a long way to reduce your tuition loan.
cons: Atlanta may not be a great city to live in for everyone. If you are looking for an erudite environment of Boston or San Francisco, you won't get it here.

review_title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant for Computer Science at Georgia Tech
job_title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros:
* Get to network with students and lots of smart people. 
* Get to influence how courses are run. 
* Get to learn course material very well. 
* Helping students is enjoyable. 
* Very flexible hours/convenient on-campus job.
cons:
* Minimum wage. 
* First semester is paid in credit. 
* Grading is very time consuming and cumbersome. 
* Proctoring tests can be somewhat boring.
* Having to proctor/grade tests during finals week is annoying.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: Great connections can be made through Tech. There are amazing research opportunities, and the professors are experts in their fields. I would go back if I needed another degree.
cons: One of the downsides to having the professors be experts in their field and being involved in the amazing projects etc. is that the instruction varies greatly between profs. Some are great, but some are not, but they are around because the pull in money and do great research.

review_title: Great School if your area is CS/ECE/ISYE
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros:
Georgia Tech has one of the best Engineering Schools all over the world. 
You can learn a lot from leading scientists/engineers in the world.
In the mid-town Atlanta, there are lot of fun for life.
cons:
Salary for graduate research/teaching assistant is a bit low considering the rising living expense in Atlanta. 
Not a particular top notch school if your field is more science/math-oriented than engineering-oriented.

review_title: It's good place for graduate study and work parttime
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: As a graduate student working as teaching assistant, professors are very understanding, won't assign you more than you can handle so that you will have enough time for research. Also students are intelligent and it won't take too much effort to explain basic stuff. You can have fair amount of scientific discussion with professors and students.
cons: I complain a lot of my working environment. The office it always cold in the winter and heat won't work and AC keeps working in winter....

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: Excellent facilities for students to work under the able guidance of experienced professors. Research can be done with a lot of freedom without too much micro-management.
cons: People can get too narrow-sided with their research. Although seminars tend to increase your knowledge, it's hard to follow the recent advancements made in the Chemical R&D.

review_title: Georgia Tech is an excellent place for research
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: Georgia Tech has a very good name among the research institutes. You can be expose to cutting-edge research in Georgia Tech. The school has many kinds of fund to support your research activities, such as comference, start-up.
cons: It is kind of competitive. In Georgia Tech you are working on the hottest topic in the world, you have to work hard to be the leader in your area.

review_title: Lab Manager and Quality improvement  Engineer
job_title: Research Technologist/Lab Manager in Atlanta, GA
pros:
Great hub of intellectuals. Strong academic work ethic.  Very friendly environment.  Respect for  each other. Rank high in education and leadership. 

Great appreciation of what each other is doing. Great benefits all around.
cons:
Hard for me to say, I like to see the positive side of GA Tech. 
Lack of grant money

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: The pay is good, and the cost of living is low. Good transport in and around the campus is provided by Georgia Tech, in addition to cabs at night -- all free. Also, the campus is in the mid-town area.
cons: The "reduced tuition" for GRAs is somewhat high: $1150 a year. Unfortunately, there's a somewhat high incidence of theft and other crime in the area, though nothing alarming. Winters can be chilly! Also, if you're planning on riding a bike, it's hard because of the ups and downs.

review_title: While studying for PhD , you'd perform research  as a contract to a company/institution
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: It is a flexible job . You work and study at the same time so the deadlines are rather flexible.
cons:
There are no benefits, just a lame health insurance package!
Raises and compensations are given very rarely
Very low  income compared to what you'll be getting as an engineer working for a company

pros: GA Tech has excellent benefits,  flex time including telecommuting ( in IT dept), family oriented environment, time off for children and family is not a problem, practice of hiring within
cons: Communication between management and employees need improvement,  Manatory 5% for retirement is deducted from salary (note this mandate applies to all school/colleges in the University System of Georgia)

review_title: Great grad school, not so much money
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: The grad school at Tech is top 10 within US for all engineering disciplines, so this puts you in the middle of a lot of very smart people.
cons: As a PhD student, they give you a stipend but take it away in the name of 'mandatory fees.' That leaves you with peanuts to live on.

pros: Working at GT is great for many reasons - but largely because of the students.  It's a vibrant place to be and campus is constantly growing and changing.  If you're interested in working at a university - and particularly if have an interest in STEM education - than Tech is a great place to work.
cons: In terms of staff positions, some of the offices at Tech are more efficient/effective than others.  I think the culture depends greatly on which role / office you are in.

review_title: very good training, lots of opportunities
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: I think we had great training, very good projects and great mentor. There are a lot of discussions among students. Good library resources, nice campus
cons: salary not very good, barely enough for living. Atlanta is not a very safe place to live, there are crimes on campus and off-campus

review_title: Great place to be a Research Assistant
pros: Access to great research projects, good support from the administration, especially for international students. The tuition discount is well worth getting the job as well. The nature of the work will vary depending on which department you work for, of course, but there are many opportunities for grad student assistants to work with other research groups and collaborate.
cons: It can be hard to balance the RA work with your class work, and Tech is notorious for a deeply invested work culture.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: As an undergraduate, I have a large class load and my mentor and principal investigator (PI) are very understanding of my hectic schedule. The facilities and faculty are some of the best of the best.
cons: I've been given a few different projects to focus on, so it can be a challenge to see a big picture at times. Also, I find myself very attached to the projects and wanting to be in the lab constantly, which can have a detrimental effect on my work-life balance.

job_title: Instructor, College Or University in Atlanta, GA
pros: Georgia Tech is a very sound technical educational institution.  Very competent faculty, good staff, great and interested students, great location (mid-town Atlanta). Its engineering programs are among the highest rated in the country, and they deserve to be.
cons: Being a state institution and state employees in a state like Georgia definitely has its disadvantages. No salary increases in six years! And I do not like being on campus with the "guns everywhere" legislation passed in Georgia last year.

pros: Working on campus as a student was amazing- my boss understood every time I had a difficult assignment or test coming up, and would allow me to send in my class schedule before each new work schedule was sent out. I was frequently told that being a student came first, and that allowed me to enjoy my job. My job allowed me to test my skills and helped me prepare myself for work after graduation.
cons: Pay was low- as expected for an on campus job .

review_title: Overall good experience working as Physics 2 TA
pros:
1. Paid well compared with other on-campus  jobs. 
2. Not too much work load to lead a lab section. You don't have to keep talking as you do for TA for other classes.
cons:
1. 3 Hour lab is very long and exhausting. 
2. I don' enjoy debugging for students
3. Time is not very flexible, you can't skip it for preparation of another exam etc.

pros: As a part-time student, managers offered as much flexibility as they could when scheduling hours around my difficult weeks in school.  Always had a good relationship with management/supervisors, and the pay was also very reasonable.
cons: I don't have any cons, everything was what I expected in the job description and found working there quite pleasant.

pros: Beautiful campus, fantastic education, in the great city of Atlanta. What more could one ask for?
cons: Unfortunately, a lot of higher ups don't listen to students, and the political situation can get kind of nasty at times. A lot of my experience has been with academic bureaucracy, which nobody likes to deal with.

review_title: Georgia Tech - A good place to work
pros: Staff and faculty strive for excellence as a university, benefits are top notch, students are highly motivated, facillities and location are superior. Atlanta is an exciting city to live in. Work/ life balance is attainable.
cons: Salary does not compare to industry jobs, Some managers are not willing to address problem employees. There is a pretty wide talent difference from area to area.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: Great students, staff, and collaboration opportunities. Core and animal facilities easy to access and relatively inexpensive. Plenty of good faculty advisers.
cons: High performance expected and good time management skills are necessary as in any top tier grad school. The different programs within BioE often creates confusion with different requirements from different departments. Living near campus is either expensive or slightly risky.

review_title: Georgia Tech is professional, adventurous, and fun!
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: Always working on innovative projects. Working there as a graduate research assistant at the School of Aerospace engineering gave me incredible opportunities to get my hands dirty and discovery new things.
cons: Georgia Tech is known for its rigorous academics, but I think they are all worth it. The salary for graduate research assistants are pretty minimal, but if you play your cards right, you can get through grad school without having to take out a loan!

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros:
There're many reasons you want to be a GRA.
1. You will get tuition waiver for whatever program you are enrolled in Georgia Tech.
2. If you are a Ph.D. student, you are actually getting paid to do your own research to your dissertation.
3. The Tech campus is great, and located in midtown Atlanta.
cons: The only con of being a GRA is you cannot take too much courses. Because, GRA work combined with too many course works will make your life miserable.
